title: As requested by TL, better parameter names.
message:
As requested by TL, better parameter names.

id -> message_id, crew_id as appropriate
crew -> crew_id
search -> search_id

The old names still work for now, but in a few months I'll drop
support for them and go back to simpler non-list based param_or_null,
param_requested functions.

title: Allow messages to be sent supplying a single recipient's fingerprint.
message:
Allow messages to be sent supplying a single recipient's fingerprint.

As requested by Mike, you can send either an existing crew ID, or a
fingerprint.  If you send a fingerprint, the server will try to find
an existing crew that has only the sender and the recipient in it, and
send the message in that crew; if it fails to find such a crew it will
create one.

title: Reference-counting based profile synchronisation, take 1
message:
Reference-counting based profile synchronisation, take 1

Not yet very well tested...  need to test with high concurrency.
Profiles are now deterministically insert, updated and deleted on
devices according to a simple reference counting scheme, so that the
client apps have profile details for everyone referenced by a match,
message or crew.

title: Refactored query to make easier to understand and hopefully equivalent...
message: Refactored query to make easier to understand and hopefully equivalent...

title: No more 'tags' or # signs.
message:
No more 'tags' or # signs.

Now, we just take all the words (so # has no special meaning, it's
just ignored because it's a non-word, and can therefore separate words
like any other punctuation or whitespace).  Each of these candidate
tags is converted to lower case.  Then we ignore the ones that are
configured as IGNORED or DELETED.  We reject searches that include a
tag that is BANNED.  We only index on the ones that are ACTIVE.  I
stole an initial list of words to ignore from a document linked from
Wikipedia.

title: Device 'match' table needed a compound primary key.
message:
Device 'match' table needed a compound primary key.

You can have two searches at the same time which both match the same
other search, so it was insufficient (and stupid) to use the matching
search's ID as a unique ID for the match.  Now it's (search,
other_search), where search is your own search's ID.

title: Now returning synchronisation results in JSON format.
message:
Now returning synchronisation results in JSON format.

As discussed with MM over icecream in the sun.  This avoids the
difficulty of parsing raw SQL scripts, since we now know that Android
SQLite wants to receive the statements one by one, but some of these
statements could be multi-line.  It also makes the synchronisation
results more like every other result the server sends, and this will
become important shortly because we're planning to include "free"
synchronisation results with other results, like create_search (watch
this space).

title: Google push notifications, version -1.
message:
Google push notifications, version -1.

"Tickle" notifications only for now, with no payload.  Need to convert
this quick and dirty "speedy-notifier" script into a proper daemon
that stays up and does exponential back-off on errors etc etc... but
generally this appears to be working...  Here is what Google tells me:

{'failure': 1,
 'canonical_ids': 0,
 'success': 0,
 'multicast_id': -1,
 'results': [{'error': 'InvalidRegistration'}]}

Which I think just says that "1234" isn't a phone.  Yeah.

title: Some early hacking for the new synchronisation model.
message:
Some early hacking for the new synchronisation model.

Devices will hit /api/1/synchronise/1234 to say they have
control.high_sequence == 1234.  The server will then decide whether it
has enough data in its event table to generate incremental change
statements, or a complete set of DELETE and INSERT statements to
reinitialise the device.  There are some special commands in SQL
comments which the device can interpret.  So far @REFRESH means that a
complete refresh follows, and the plan is that @INSERT/@UPDATE/@DELETE
<uri> will list changes in a way the device can hopefully use to
update any GUIs etc.  Watch this space...

title: Remove deleted searches from output of 'searches'.
message:
Remove deleted searches from output of 'searches'.

Explanation: when searches are deleted via 'delete_search', they are
not actually deleted immediatley, instead they are set to DELETED
status, and cleaned up later.  I have some (half-baked) thoughts about
how the deletion would be replicated to various devices (for example
the search owner's potentially several devices, and also other devices
that are showing matches which must now disappear).  To be discussed,
with beverages.

For now: this commit excludes them from view, but also shows the
status explicitly (ie ACTIVE).  Since DK reported the bug that
delete_search apparently didn't work!

title: Automatically tags from query string; reversed PROVIDE/SEEK
message:
Automatically tags from query string; reversed PROVIDE/SEEK

After discussion with Dietmar about topics raised in issue #20:

1.  PROVIDE and SEEK are now reverse.  SEEK is always the side with a
radius (the person who is prepared to move).  This could be a waiter
seeking a job anywhere in London, or hungry person in search of a
hamburger.  PROVIDE is always the fixed location with no radius (the
person providing a job or a hamburger).

2.  Instead of the device sending a list of tags, it simply sends a
query string written by a human, which includes Twitter-style
hash-tags.  "#waiter and #bartender seeks work".  In future we might
also extract non-hash-prefixed words if they match a pre-existing tag,
but for now there must be at least one tag with a hash.

title: Schema redesign (part 1)
message:
Schema redesign (part 1)

All database objects now created in schema "speedycrew".  This is
tidier (we'll leave "public" to PostGIS since it likes to create a few
magic things in there), and allowed us to blow away and recreate the
schema with ease (just run drop.sql and create.sql).

Moved to the more general term "tag" rather than "skill".  Created
"search".  Watch this space...
